image.altText: A box for the ordering of candidates in South Australia's First Nations Voice to Parliament elections.

props.synopsis: Polling booths will open across South Australia today for the state’s inaugural First Nations Voice to Parliament election.

title.children: First Nations people vote in first SA Voice to Parliament election

image.altText: A composite image of two men (Ted O'Brien and Chris Bowen) superimposed over solar panels and wind turbines and nuclear plant

props.synopsis: Our fleet of coal plants is falling apart, forcing us to rethink our power supply and consider an urgent question for both climate and energy security reasons: what will fill that gap?

title.children: Nuclear power in Australia — a silver bullet or white elephant?

image.altText: Black and white wedding photo of murder victim Kelly Wilkinson smiling.

props.synopsis: Within weeks of telling her family how fearful she was of her estranged husband, he brutally murdered the 27-year-old mother-of-three in an unexpected attack in her own  backyard.

title.children: Kelly Wilkinson had a six-word code to use when she was in fear of her life – a message she never got to send

image.altText: A yellow lease sign outside a row of terrace houses.

props.synopsis: Politicians are all too aware that a metaphorical poverty freight train is coming for a generation of renters, but can a collision be avoided, asks David Taylor.

title.children: A generation of renters is staring down poverty in retirement. Let's break down why

image.altText: Ben Manenti wearing an Italian flag over his shoulders

props.synopsis: State cricketer Ben Manenti and brother Harry have been called up by their country — but the national team in question doesn't wear green and gold. The brothers find themselves alongside Sir Donald Bradman on the list of Australian cricketers with Italian heritage.

title.children: When state cricketer Ben Manenti got a national call-up for Italy, he 'thought it was a p***-take'

image.altText: Close up photo of Eric the dolphin swimming.

props.synopsis: Eric has become a popular regular at Port Broughton in South Australia, but there are safety concerns for the dolphin and swimmers after complaints to the local council about people getting "rough" with him.

title.children: Swimmers warned to leave friendly dolphin alone after reports of people trying to ride him

image.altText: A woman smiles with short brown hair, she wears a blue dress and colourful necklace, she sits at a wooden desk

props.synopsis: Crystal Petch looks like any other busy mother of two, but on the inside, her brain and immune system are working against her. She says being part of a regional support group for South Australians with similar life experiences makes it easier.

title.children: Working mum who suddenly experienced slurred speech finds her 'village' with regional support for MS

image.altText: Krystal and Anastasia Marshall hug and smile.

props.synopsis: Anastasia Marshall, who was charged with murder after her ex-wife Krystal Marshall was found dead at the scene of a house fire in Adelaide's south, is granted home detention bail, but police prosecutors ask the Supreme Court to review the decision.

title.children: Ex-wife accused of murdering Krystal Marshall granted home detention bail

image.altText: Malinauskas refugees

props.synopsis: New arrivals in SA from war-torn countries will receive additional support from the state government as part of a new humanitarian package.

title.children: SA unveils additional support for new arrivals fleeing conflict

image.altText: MCU of former Boeing Quality Manager John Barnett sitting in his house wearing a white open collared shirt and grey jacket

props.synopsis: Former Boeing worker John Barnett's lawyer describes the whistleblower as an "honest, open and sincere" man of integrity and said he paid "the highest price" for speaking out, in his first interview since his client's death.

title.children: At 4am in South Carolina, a Boeing whistleblower's lawyer dialled an Australian mobile number to share 'some news'

image.altText: Storm clouds drop heavy rain in the distance on a western Queensland property

props.synopsis: The forecast is above La Niña's average occurrence of once every four years, and if eventuated would represent the fourth La Niña in five years.

title.children: La Niña odds now sit at 80 per cent. How will it affect our weather?

image.altText: Jackie and Julian Pagani are married on the beach

props.synopsis: The hotel rooms are vacant, the cafes are empty and the only road into this coastal hamlet is impassable. Tourist operators in Australia's far north are now questioning how they will survive.

title.children: This couple has spent months burning fuel and money to power a campsite no-one can visit

image.altText: A fashion model stands in the spotlight.

props.synopsis: Tokyo's strange fashion week, burnt effigies of India's PM and music lessons on the decline in China — the Asia Pacific this week in pictures.

title.children: Japan's bizarre fashion week and burning effigies in India: The Asia Pacific this week in pictures

image.altText: Clare O'Neil speaks during Question Time

props.synopsis: The federal government is promising greater public transparency over its handling of almost 150 people recently released from detention, as it fears further legal challenges will dramatically reshape parts of the nation's immigration system.

title.children: Government pledges transparency as it braces for reshaping of immigration system

image.altText: Perth Police drug testing kit

props.synopsis: Roadside instant drug testing is under scrutiny after an Adelaide driver falsely tested positive to methamphetamine, but experts say the benefits of their use may outweigh the risks.

title.children: A false positive on a roadside drug test saw a man lose his licence. How widely are they used in Australia?

image.altText: A blue and brown sign reading "Mount Gambier Courthouse" with a brick building in the back

props.synopsis: An Kingston SE man in his 80s will likely die in prison after he was sentenced for sexually abusing children across 30 years.

title.children: Elderly SA man sentenced to 25 years' jail for child sexual abuse spanning decades

image.altText: A woman with curly hair and a printed top holds a stack of paperwork outside Darwin local court.

props.synopsis: The remote community of Angurugu, on Groote Eylandt, has hosted its first community court sitting since the new system was legislated last year. The government aims to roll the system out across five more remote communities before the end of the year.

title.children: In this remote courtroom, Aboriginal elders sit next to the judge

image.altText: a composite image of three candidates' portraits

props.synopsis: A potential "Greenslide" in Brisbane, numerous mayors running unopposed, and big pre-poll numbers — local council elections are underway.

title.children: Potential 'Greenslide' in LNP territory tipped for Brisbane City Council as Queenslanders head to polls for local elections

image.altText: A pile of folded ballots at the base of a clear box.

props.synopsis: Vladimir Putin has towered over Russian politics for more than two decades — this is how he does it, from barring the strongest opposition leaders to stuffing the ballot boxes.

title.children: 'Everything in Russia is fraudulent': Inside Putin's 'sham' election

image.altText: A dark haired woman looks at a man

props.synopsis: While the Photoshop fail may haunt the Prince and Princess of Wales for years to come, this is not the first misstep by their office. Experts say it shows the challenges this ancient institution faces in a modern media environment, one they must meet if they hope to persist for generations to come.

title.children: 'Either stupidity or willful ignorance': What's going on in William and Kate's royal court?

image.altText: An elderly woman in a white suit stands in front of a small white car.

props.synopsis: NSW is the only state to offer modified licences as the government aims to strike a balance between elderly people maintaining their independence and managing risk.

title.children: Judy didn't want to do an 'ageist' on-road driving test when she turned 85, so she opted for a restricted licence

image.altText: A man sits in a wheelchair smiling with the beach in the background

props.synopsis: Advocates say many people with disabilities have a "love-hate relationship" with  beaches, and are calling for more funding for equitable access to the sand and surf.

title.children: 'Locked out of life': Australia has 12,000 beaches, but only 150 have access for people with disabilities

image.altText: A man in a black shirt and glasses stands in a backyard with e-bikes, some under tarp and some not.

props.synopsis: Lithium-ion batteries are a key aspect to transitioning to greener energies, but they're also contributing to a spate of fires across the country. One problem is the type of products they're in.

title.children: Why are there so many 'lithium-ion battery-related fires' now?

image.altText: A montage of pictures of flood scenes

props.synopsis: After a 'once in a lifetime' flood, the former manager of Australia's biggest sheep station speaks of the devastation he is feeling after widespread flooding caused chaos in WA's outback this week.

title.children: It's being billed as a once in a lifetime flood. Here's the pathway to recovery for the Nullarbor

image.altText: Paul Alexander drinking his coffee with his caregiver Kathryn Gaines who is eating cereal

props.synopsis: Paul Alexander spent most of his life confined to a breathing machine that looks like a mini submarine. Here's how he spent his life.

title.children: This man lived in an iron lung for more than 70 years. Here's how he spent his life

image.altText: A curved sandstone wall with the words 'Cranbrook School  Murray Rose Aquatic & Fitness Centre'.

props.synopsis: A teacher sent sexually explicit texts to a former student five years after he was kept on by the headmaster of Sydney's prestigious Cranbrook School after admitting to another former pupil he had looked up girls' skirts.

title.children: 'I just feel sick': Former student sent sexually explicit texts by Cranbrook teacher

image.altText: A women stands between two men. The men hold objects that appear to be shields. All are smiling.

props.synopsis: In the cane fields of North Queensland, these Indigenous artefacts lay hidden. Now that they have been returned, traditional owners hope more will follow.

title.children: Laying beneath cane fields, Indigenous artefacts link traditional owners to dark past

image.altText: An aerial image of a burnt-down mansion with a swimming pool and greenery around

props.synopsis: Delevingne shares several Instagram stories seeming to refer to the fire, which firefighters spent two hours putting out.

title.children: Cara Delevingne says her 'heart is broken' after house in Los Angeles is destroyed in fire

image.altText: An old drawing of vessel SS Nemesis.

props.synopsis: A technician looking for lost shipping containers off the New South Wales coast noticed an anomaly on his screen. It turned out to be the wreck of the SS Nemesis, which disappeared in a storm 120 years ago.

title.children: How a chance discovery helped solve the 120-year-old mystery of the SS Nemesis

image.altText: A bright green moth against a black background

props.synopsis: Natural selection is very good at shedding superfluous traits, but in an evolutionary decluttering that would make Marie Kondo proud, some species have taken it to the extreme.

title.children: Which animal is the ultimate minimalist? These creatures truly embrace the 'less is more' life

image.altText: Ella Rossanis' chocolate cherry loaf with sour cream icing on a baking tray, with four slices laying on their side.

props.synopsis: This one-bowl chocolate cake is made special with the addition of cherry jam and sour cream. The icing is optional, but very much recommended.

title.children: This rich, chocolate cherry loaf comes together in a single bowl

image.altText: Finneas applauds and Billie Eilish bows after performing onstage at the 2024 Oscars.

props.synopsis: Barbie The Album brought big stars together for the ultimate moment of modern-day poptimism. Its success at this year's awards season comes as little surprise.

title.children: 'Modern-day poptimism': Why Barbie's sole Oscar was for its soundtrack

image.altText: A man in a while shirt looks at the camera while standing in front of a film set in the desert

props.synopsis: From riding sandworms to creating an entire new planet, Australian cinematographer Greig Fraser shares how he created the look of Dune: Part Two.

title.children: How do you ride a sandworm? The Aussie who won an Oscar for shooting 'unfilmable' movie Dune, explains

image.altText: Spliced image of four People of Pacific and Maori heritage. Two women and two men.

props.synopsis: For many children of Pacific migrants, this generation is living out the dreams of their ancestors. But breaking glass ceilings also means getting a few cuts and bruises along the way.

title.children: 'We're not just rugby players': Young Pacific people are breaking glass ceilings in Australia

image.altText: Miquette Abercrombie sitting on the steps of parliament with a sign hanging behind her that says COVID and pillow cases around.

props.synopsis: Thousands of Australians are still battling the life-changing impacts of long COVID which, despite significant advances in understanding of how it impacts the body, continues to have no proven treatment.

title.children: After 700 days of long COVID, Miquette is lying down on the steps of Parliament House
